title.rendered: Scam or a smart move for marijuana companies?

content.rendered:
Yes, gentlemen, the NFT boom, as could not be imagined, is approaching the world of THC and CBD. Already various designers make their own images involving the cannabis.

Marijuana companies are deploying non-fungible tokens (NFTs) to build excitement around new products, verify test results, and sell consumers exclusive offers.

Defined as digital art tied to cryptocurrency and blockchain technology, proponents of NFTs say they are the future of the next iteration of the internet, often called the metaverse.

Skepticism surrounds NFTs

Skeptics say the tokens, which took the art market by storm and are now being rolled out by major companies, have minimal value.

Critics also see the cryptocurrency sector, in general, as a pyramid scheme riddled with scams.

However, not a few marijuana and hemp companies are curious enough to explore the space with an open mind.

“From a business perspective, you can’t ignore the NFT market,” said Sammy Dorf, co-founder and chief growth officer of the NFT company. cannabis Verano Holdings, based in Chicago.

“Cannabis is evolving so rapidly from so many angles that we think this could be an opportunity to attract different customers.”

Blockchain data company Chainalysis estimates that the NFT market was worth $41 billion in 2021, according to Markets Insider.

Here here’s a look at how top companies are getting into tokens

Under Armor released an NFT collection based on the shoes worn by Golden State Warriors point guard Stephen Curry when he broke the NBA’s all-time record for career 3-pointers.

Adidas has partnered with the Bored Ape Yacht Club to offer NFTs that give shoppers exclusive access to purchase real-world merchandise, among other perks.

Nike bought RTFKT, which makes NFTs and shoes just for the metaverse.

Entrepreneur Gary Vaynerchuk announced that he will open a restaurant where patrons must purchase NFTs to gain membership.

Jeffrey Welsh, an intellectual and entertainment attorney at the Denver-based law firm Vicente Sederberg, said the “low hanging fruit” for marijuana companies is building memberships around NFTs that are associated with cool or unique digital assets that, in turn, they are connected to products such as popular or exotic varieties.

“We have not yet seen the power of NFTs in cannabis,” he added.

NFT COA

In November, the Boca Raton, Florida-based ACS Laboratory, which tests both marijuana and hemp, released a certificate of analysis (COA) as an NFT during the Art Basel Miami Beach art fair.

The company has partnered with Blockticity, which bills itself as “the leader in guaranteed certificates of authenticity for the most valuable possessions,” to offer the proof COA on the blockchain.

Roger Brown, president of ACS Laboratory, said he was initially skeptical.
“I absolutely thought, ‘Who is going to buy a digital image?’” he said.

Brown realized once he understood that offering COAs like NFTs on the blockchain could help authenticate test results.

His lab receives calls every week with questions about the validity of test results. COAs are often changed after they leave your lab.

NFT technology

With this new technology, a business or consumer can scan a QR code and obtain an NFT from the COA, which is date-stamped and certified.

For the initial delivery at Art Basel, ACS Laboratory sold about 100 NFTs at $100 each, according to Brown.

He doesn’t think of NFT gaming as a revenue generator, but instead sees it as a way to bolster consumer confidence and strengthen brand reputation.

In an unexpected twist, ACS Laboratory is now fielding calls from consumers who want the company to produce COA NFTs for a particular strain just because that consumer might like that strain.

Now he has a whole team working to get COAs on the blockchain.
“It’s coming full circle,” Brown said.

How to avoid being scammed

While fraudsters exist in the NFT space, that’s no different than in the business world, Vicente Sederberg’s Welsh said.

To avoid operating in a questionable space, he recommends that companies do as much research as possible before listing or “minting” NFTs.

It also recommends that companies buy and sell tokens on OpenSea, the more established marketplace.

Additionally, Welsh advises staying away from pump-and-dump scams.

The unregulated cryptocurrency market provides an opportunity for these types of schemes, where an individual or group buys large amounts of “coins” to increase demand and price.

Those same traders exaggerate the merit of cryptocurrency in particular, often using social media platforms or influencers.

Once investors rush to buy the coin, the same group sheds their holdings, causing prices to drop.

The most well-known pump and dump in cryptocurrency to date occurred with a coin called EthereumMax.

Kim Kardashian and boxer Floyd Mayweather promoted the coin through social media.

EthereumMax has lost up to 97% of its value since June and prompted the filing of a class action lawsuit.

Cannabis companies looking to mint NFTs, or create originals, should also be aware of the potential to infringe on pre-existing intellectual property

For example, a series of NFTs are created to resemble a famous fashion logo, say Louis Vuitton.

The high-end luxury company owns many trademarks, and if an NFT is launched to intentionally resemble something that is famous or well-known, expect a trademark lawsuit from the famous brand.

“Just because it’s an NFT doesn’t mean IP considerations are out of the window,” Welsh said. “A lot of times, people don’t really pay attention to who owns the intellectual property.

“A wave of litigation is coming at some point.”

One major gray area: The NFT market is not part of the real-world legal system, and as of yet, there is no judge or courtroom in the metaverse.
